originalTitle: Russian 'pick-up artist' accused of secretly filming women in Ghana
title: Big Rules for Big Smiles: Learning About Asking Permission in Ghana!
content:
Hello, my wonderful friends across Africa and beyond! Your kid-friendly news reporter is here with a very important story from a beautiful country in Africa called Ghana. Ghana is a sunny place with lots of friendly people and amazing culture! Today, we’re going to talk about something super important: asking for permission. It's like when you ask your grown-up if you can have a cookie or play a game. Asking makes everything fair and happy!

What Happened in Ghana?

Imagine you are playing with your friends, having a great time. Now, imagine someone came along and started taking pictures or videos of you without asking you first. How would that make you feel? Maybe a little surprised, or even a bit uncomfortable, right? Well, that’s a little like what this story is about. There was a man who came to visit Ghana from a far-away country called Russia. The news tells us that this man is *accused* of taking videos of people without asking them first. *Accused* means someone is saying he did it, but it's still being investigated to make sure everything is clear. Taking pictures or videos of people, especially in private moments, without their permission, is not kind or fair.

Why Is Asking Permission So Important?

Asking for permission is like magic words that make everyone feel safe and respected! When you ask, you are showing that you care about other people's feelings and their space. It's a big rule we all learn from when we are very little. Think about it: If you want to borrow your friend's toy, you ask, "Can I please play with your toy?" If you want to draw on a paper, you ask, "Is it okay if I use this paper?" It’s the same with taking pictures or videos of people. We should always ask, "Is it okay if I take your picture?" or "Can I record this moment?" Did you know? Asking for permission helps build trust. When you ask, people know you respect them, and they feel safe around you. It makes friendships and communities stronger!

Everyone Deserves Privacy

Everyone has something called 'privacy.' Privacy means having your own space and your own choices about what you share with others. It's like your own special bubble that only you decide who can come into. Your bedroom is private, right? You get to decide who comes in and what happens there. Your feelings are private too, until you choose to share them. Pictures and videos, especially of private moments, are also part of someone's privacy. Taking them without asking is like popping their privacy bubble without their permission, and that's not okay. It's very important to remember that our phones and cameras are powerful tools. They can capture special moments, but we must use them wisely and respectfully. Always, always, always ask before you click that button to take a photo or video of someone, especially if it's something personal to them.

What Is Ghana Doing About It?

The people and leaders in Ghana care a lot about everyone who lives there and visits. They want to make sure everyone feels safe and respected. Because this man is accused of doing something that broke important rules about privacy and asking permission, Ghana wants to talk to him about it. They want him to understand why what he is accused of doing was not okay. Ghana has asked the man's home country, Russia, for help. They want the man to come back to Ghana so they can have a proper conversation about what happened. It shows that Ghana is serious about keeping its people safe and making sure rules are followed. This process of asking another country for help with someone who broke rules is a big and important step. Did you know? Countries work together, just like friends, to solve big problems. When something like this happens, countries talk to each other to make sure justice is done and people are protected.

Learning from This Story

So, what can we learn from this story, my friends? We learn that asking for permission is a superpower! It makes the world a better, kinder, and safer place for everyone. Here are some super tips for you: * **Always Ask:** Before you take a picture or video of someone, always ask them first. Say, "May I please take your picture?" If they say no, that's okay! Respect their choice. * **Think Before You Share:** If you have a picture or video of someone, don't share it online or with others without their permission. * **Your Privacy Matters Too:** If someone tries to take your picture or video without asking, it's okay to say, "Please don't do that," or "I don't want my picture taken." You have the right to your own privacy. * **Tell a Grown-Up:** If anything ever makes you feel uncomfortable, or if someone takes your picture when you don't want them to, tell a trusted grown-up like your parent, teacher, or guardian right away. Ghana is a wonderful place, and its people deserve to feel happy and safe. This story reminds us all about the importance of being respectful and kind to one another. Keep shining brightly, my friends, and remember to always ask!

Fun Facts About Ghana!

Did you know Ghana is famous for its delicious cocoa, which is used to make chocolate? It's one of the biggest producers in the world! Ghana was also the first country in sub-Saharan Africa to gain independence from colonial rule in 1957. That's a super cool piece of history! The capital city is Accra, a busy and exciting place. People in Ghana are known for their hospitality and vibrant culture, including beautiful kente cloth and wonderful music. What a special place!
summary: A man visiting Ghana is accused of secretly filming people without asking, reminding everyone about the very important rule of always asking for permission to take pictures or videos, and how Ghana is working to make sure its people feel safe and respected.
whyMatters: This story is important because it teaches us a super valuable lesson: we must always ask for permission before taking someone's picture or video, and everyone has a right to their own privacy to feel safe and respected. It shows that Ghana cares a lot about protecting its people.

originalTitle: Planned US-funded baby vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau blasted by WHO
title: Planned US-funded baby vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau blasted by WHO
content: Giving some newborns in Guinea-Bissau an established hepatitis B treatment but not others is "unethical", it says.

title: Pereira announced as Forest boss on 18-month deal
